question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for reducing lethal vessel strikes on large whales?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two studies reported that setting and enforcing vessel speed limits reduced deaths from collisions: a before-and-after study in the Indian River estuarine system (USA) reported fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas, and a before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean (USA) found fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths during periods with speed limits in key habitats [2777]. No studies were found evaluating the effects of diverting shipping routes [2754], using onboard observers to detect mammals and alter course or speed [2755], or using remote tools to detect mammals and alter course or speed [2757]. The action documents do not report cost or cost-effectiveness data for these methods [2754; 2755; 2757; 2777].

summary_statements: Two studies reported that setting and enforcing vessel speed limits reduced deaths from collisions.
A before-and-after study in the Indian River estuarine system (USA) reported fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.
A before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean (USA) found fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths during periods with speed limits in key habitats.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of diverting shipping routes.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of using onboard observers to detect mammals and alter course or speed.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of using remote tools to detect mammals and alter course or speed.
The action documents do not report cost or cost-effectiveness data for methods to reduce lethal vessel strikes on large whales.
